Transform your creations into unstealable masterpieces with IdentaMark. Your content, your rules—protected like never before.
Choose your process to embed or extract a watermark into your images with confidence.
Embedding: "Embed a system-generated watermark into your image to enable traceability and ensure copyright protection."
Extraction: "Retrieve the embedded watermark data for analysis and evaluation purposes."
Attacking: "Test watermark strength through compression, noise, and other attacks."
Choose your process to embed or extract a watermark into your audio with confidence.
Embedding: "Embed a system-generated watermark into your audio to enable traceability and ensure copyright protection."
Extraction: "Retrieve the embedded watermark data for analysis and evaluation purposes."

PSNR (Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio) measures the quality difference between the original media and the watermarked version.

• Unit: dB (decibels)
• Common Scale:
 - > 40 dB: Excellent quality
 - 30–40 dB: Good quality
 - < 30 dB: Noticeable degradation

SNR (Signal-to-Noise Ratio) indicates how strong the signal is compared to noise, especially in audio.

• Unit: dB
• Common Scale:
 - > 20 dB: Excellent
 - 10–20 dB: Acceptable
 - < 10 dB: Poor quality

Payload represents the amount of watermark data embedded into the media.

• Units:
 - bits (total amount)
 - bpp (bits per pixel) for image
 - bps (bits per sample) for audio

• Higher payload increases capacity but may reduce media quality.

bpp (bits per pixel) indicates how many bits of watermark are embedded per pixel in an image.

• Used in image watermarking.
• Lower bpp values (e.g., < 0.01) help maintain visual quality.
• bpp = total watermark bits / (image width × height)

bps (bits per sample) indicates how many bits of watermark are embedded per audio sample.

• Used in audio watermarking.
• Lower bps values (e.g., < 0.01) help maintain audio quality.
• bps = total watermark bits / number of audio samples

BER (Bit Error Rate) is the ratio of incorrectly extracted watermark bits to the total embedded bits.

• Lower BER indicates better extraction accuracy.
• BER = 0 means perfect extraction with no errors.
"Image Quality Characteristics Information"
"Audio Quality Characteristics Information"
Attack Type Information
No modification; the image remains untouched.
Applies JPEG compression, possibly reducing visual quality.
Rotates the image, shifting pixels and watermark location.
Horizontally flips the image, reversing pixel layout.
Randomly crops part of the image, possibly removing watermark data.
Scales the image then resizes it back, possibly distorting watermark.
Applies uniform scaling to both dimensions of the image.
Applies non-uniform scaling on X/Y, warping the image.
Randomly removes rows or columns from the image.
Applies both rotation and resizing distortions.
Applies random geometric distortion to the image layout.
Combines geometric distortion with JPEG compression.
Smooths the image and removes high-frequency detail using LPF.
Sharpens the image, enhancing edges and fine structures.
Adjusts image contrast via histogram equalization.
Modifies brightness/contrast using gamma correction.
Reduces number of colors in the image, simplifying appearance.
Adds random noise, disrupting the watermark.
Modifies pixels using local statistical averaging.
Adds a new watermark on top of the existing one.
Attempts to guess the watermark using additional information.
Smooths the image using a median filter to reduce noise.
Audio Attack Descriptions
Low-Pass Filter (LPF) removes high-frequency components from the audio signal, which may include embedded watermark data.
Band-Pass Filter (BPF) allows only a certain frequency band, removing others and potentially damaging watermark information outside that band.
Requantization reduces the audio bit-depth (e.g., from 16-bit to 8-bit), lowering quality and affecting watermark accuracy.
Additive White Noise introduces random noise into the audio, masking or distorting the watermark.
Resampling changes the sample rate of the audio, which may disrupt the embedded watermark structure.
Time-Scale Modification changes the duration (speed up or slow down) without affecting pitch. It alters time-domain watermark patterns.
Linear Speed Change modifies playback speed linearly, shifting time positions of embedded watermark signals.
Pitch Shifting adjusts the pitch without changing duration, potentially corrupting frequency-based watermarking.
Equalizer modifies certain frequency bands. Boosting or cutting can remove watermark data in those bands.
Echo adds delayed repetitions of audio signal, possibly hiding the watermark within the echo.
MP3 Compression applies lossy encoding that removes "less important" data, which may include watermark bits.
